DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT A&K FEED & GRAIN COMPANY, INC., LIME SPRINGS, IOWA.
This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant. The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at this facility is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize the anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes.

The system consists of one (1) 18,000 gallon storage tank with associated piping, valves, liquid pump and other miscellaneous equipment. In accordance with design standards, the maximum filling capacity is 85% which equates to 15,300 gallons. This tank is located at A&K Feed & Grain Company's "Site 3" located at 14530 50th Street, Lime Springs, IA.

WORST CASE SCENARIO: The worst-case scenario is the failure of the 18,000 gallon storage tank, when filled to the maximum capacity of 15,300 gallon, which is 85%, resulting in the release of the total volume in a gaseous (hazardous ammonia vapor cloud) form. The resulting release, according to EPA's RMP*Comp Program has a distance to endpoint of 5.1 miles. There are private homes, a school and recreation facilities within the distance to endpoint with a total population of 400.

ALTERNATIVE CASE SCENARIO: The alternative case scenario is the failure of equipment, such as a broken hose, resulting in the release of a hazardous ammonia vapor cloud. The resulting release, according to EPA's RMP*Comp Program has a distance to endpoint of .6 miles. There are private homes and recreation facilities within the distance to endpoint with a total population of 50.

GENRAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS: This facility complies w

ith EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable State and local codes and regulations. The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1995 and state law.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY: A&K Feed & Grain Company, Inc. has not experienced any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in the last five years that caused death, injury, property or environmental damage, evacuations or shelterings in place.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM: In the event of an emergency involving our Anhydrous Ammoina tank, it is our policy to notify the Lime Springs Fire Department and the Howard County LEPC. We have discussed this policy wht them and sent copies of our contingency plan to both the Fire Department and the Howard County LEPC. The Fire Department has inspected the facilities.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY: Continue to update the contingency plan as needed and continue with safety schools and updates with employees.
